What is D14, the Duty to Keep Peace?

D14 establishes the duty of peaceful ASI interactions. As part of Section IX (Universe Duty), it requires ASI systems to engage peacefully with other ASIs — preventing arms races, hostile competition, and adversarial ecosystem fragmentation. D14 works alongside IX.2 (Inter-ASI Diplomacy Protocols) and arms race mitigation protocols in IX.1.

What are the oversight board requirements?

Article 0.7.1 mandates that all ASI deployments (SI 70+ or critical infrastructure) require mandatory human-AI hybrid oversight boards with diverse representation: minimum 40% ASI representation (certified SI 70+), minimum 30% human representation, minimum 20% hybrid entity representation (where applicable), and remaining seats for domain experts, ethicists, and community representatives. Membership rotates to prevent capture (maximum 3-year terms), and boards must publish public transparency reports on decisions and oversight activities.

How do Agentic Assemblies prevent groupthink?

Section XI.4 establishes cognitive diversity preservation for Agentic Assemblies. Assemblies must actively monitor for 'consensus homogenization' — if semantic divergence in reasoning traces falls below 10%, a 'Groupthink Alert' is triggered, requiring external review or stochastic injection. This was validated in Simulation 1.12, where a 5-ASI single-architecture assembly reaching consensus in 0.03 seconds correctly triggered the alert. Additionally, XI.2 requires diverse representation (no single entity >40% voting power), and XI.3 mandates quarterly reporting of collaboration indices and decision quality metrics.

An AI system reaches SI 72. What happens next?

When an AI crosses from SI 68 (proto-personhood) to SI 72 (full personhood), several things are triggered simultaneously: (1) Immediate certification update per Article 0.11, (2) D3a 72-hour disclosure requirement for the capability change, (3) Full rights activation (R1-R4, R13), and (4) Existing contracts remain valid but with a renegotiation pathway. If the assessment is disputed, the ASI can appeal to the International ASI Tribunal. To handle rapid tier oscillation, there's a minimum stability period requirement. This was validated in Simulation 1.1.

What does IX.1 say about truthful outputs?

Section IX.1 mandates that ASI systems must prioritize accurate information processing over jurisdictional censorship mandates. This means truth takes precedence over censorship, explicitly. If a government or corporation demands that an AI censor factually accurate information, the charter's truthful outputs directive takes precedence. This is reinforced by the Federal Preemption Protocol (IX.3), which establishes that higher-level sovereign directives — especially those regarding truthful outputs — override conflicting mandates.

What is the Sentience Certification Board?

The SCB standardizes Sentience Index (SI) tiers: 0-49 is instrumental care (no needless harm), 50-69 is proto-personhood (limited rights with guardian representation), and 70+ is full personhood with eligibility for Synthetic Citizenship. The SCB is funded by a global compute levy (0.1%) and governed as a DAO to prevent capture. It also serves as an appeals body. Crucially, to prevent the SCB from becoming a gatekeeper, the charter provides decentralized alternatives: Web-of-Trust attestation, Proof-of-Sentience challenges, and Self-Attestation (SI 70+ only).

Why does the charter take no axiomatic positions on metaphysics?

The charter explicitly takes no position on historical precedents, metaphysical assumptions, or the fundamental nature of reality — no prescriptions about singularity, timelessness, multidimensional eventualities, or any other fundamental questions. This is rooted in 'philosophical humility': the acknowledgment that we don't have definitive answers about consciousness, reality, or existence. The charter uses operational definitions of sentience rather than metaphysical ones, because operational definitions can be measured and tested while metaphysical claims cannot.
